content: today I want to explore how you can make some pretty convincing looking wood
siding for your miniature builds using only food packaging rescued from the
recycling bin hey guys welcome back to Blackmagic craft right now is a very
difficult time for a lot of people the whole world as a matter of fact and
right now is a time when you should be doing everything that is within your
power to self isolate and social distance yourself from everyone stay
away from people right now in every way you can this is not the time for
unnecessary trips to the store to buy hobby supplies don't don't do it right
now is a time to be resourceful it's time to stay at home and use whatever
you have on hand and as crafters we're well trained to be resourceful I want to
take this opportunity to show you how you can rescue some packaging from your
recycling bin and use it in terrain making model building dollhouse building
whatever kind of miniature hobby you have you can turn this into really
nice-looking wood siding the first thing you're gonna need to do is rescue a box
from your recycling bin while you could make these strips freehand I highly
recommend marking out some lines to keep your siding strips consistent now you
can make these any size you want I think that half inch increments are a really
nice basic generic starting place if you're planning on using this for builds
that will be used with 28 to 32 millimeter scale miniatures keep in mind
that whatever size you make these strips going to visibly be smaller in the end
because you're gonna overlap your pieces once you got that marked out you want to
try to add some wood grain to the material this is the most challenging
and limiting thing about this kind of chipboard cards
material is that it's hard to put wood grain on it I found that the most
effective tool for this is a really sharp nail like sculpting tool you want
something that is sharp and will make a pretty deep groove without completely
cutting through the paper you don't want to use an exacto knife for this you can
try something like a multi pronged metal comb or brush or a saw blade with wide
teeth all that can kind of work in different ways but I found this shape in
particular like a nail head to be most effective although it's a little bit
slower than something like a comb the important thing is that you do this step
now before cutting out your strips once you're happy with your texture you can
go ahead and cut those strips out and you want to I mean at least I want to if
I want a organic look to not do straight lines if you're going for a really
modern look sure straight lines but if you're looking for
a more rustic hand-hewn kind of historical fantasy look cut a wavy line
and I'll give you a lot of variants and it's going to look really great in the
end personally I like to reset my line and cut on my mark
before doing the next one so that things don't go too out of control but this is
optional
once you have a pile of these strips made you can start attaching them to
your substrate now I'm just using a little example piece here but in reality
you would have built a house or a ship or whatever shape you're applying this
to out of whatever material you want cardboard XPS foam blocks foam core
whatever you just got to glue the strips to your substrate and go nuts
I recommend hot glue for this it's gonna be less likely to cause warping of your
structure than something like PVA glue and it's gonna attach much more quickly
start from the bottom work your way up overlapping your pieces and let your
lengths run wild cut off the excess after and add some lap joints just like
you would when doing real siding or hardwood flooring once your piece is
totally covered in your siding you want to do something to seal and harden it
obviously my go-to method is my Mod Podge mixed with black paint in a pinch
if you got to be resourceful you can use some watered-down PVA glue but if you
have the option use Mod Podge as it's far less likely to cause warping and
when you're painting it it won't get reactivated with watery paint so it's a
bit better but PVA glue if you have to now for the painting there's a lot of
different ways you can do wood and I tend to do it differently every time I
like to start by putting on a coat of a really matte pure black then take your
pick of wood under color I like using a golden kind of ochre e l OE kind of
color but you can use like a tan or a nutmeg a brown burnt umber take your
pick each little different kind of color is going to slightly change the final
look of the trick here though is that you want to really water down this paint
and only put a thin coating on and then afterwards it's going to look better
just trust me put on a thin coat then you can move on to dry brushing I like
to use a gray or a off-white or ten to dry-brush all of the edges and this
kind of weathers the wood and also gives it some dimensionality and really picks
apart those layer lines you can skip this step and save it for after the wash
you or you can do it before or you can do both it's up to you and each
different way will slightly change the way the final piece looks the most
important part of this technique is your wash and I like using a combination of
brown wash and black wash the more aged and rustic I want things to look the
more black wash I'm gonna put on the piece but I like doing a slurry of both
and I do have a recipe for a homemade black wash that you can make yourself
and I will link it in the cards up there now if you find that after your washes
you want to dry brush again like I said go ahead and if you're like me and you
think I didn't like the way that turned out just put another wash on it
seriously you can just keep doing this as many times as you want and each time
is actually just gonna give a little bit more subtle detail just don't go crazy
at some point you just gotta stop that's pretty simple like really I
really love the way that this looks I actually kind of in some ways prefer it
over my usual foam wood technique because the material is so thin it's a
much more realistic scale it's hard to work with foam that thin the downside of
course is that it's really hard to get noticeable wood grain it's more subtle
but it still looks pretty dang great you can apply this to all sorts of builds
building ships whatever go nuts build a dang house and if you don't have
something to build right now maybe use some of this time to just whip up a
whole huge batch of these strips put them in a container for future use for
when you're planning on making that Chapel or cabin or whatever guard tower
I hope you guys found this video useful I hope it helps you you know take your
mind off things for a bit and kill some time and get through this difficult
situation if you liked this video hit the like button put a comment below
don't forget to be kind to each other right now if you need to pick up any
materials though again really don't go out right now do some now's the time for
online shopping so if you do want to pick up some tools and materials and you
want to help me get through this difficult time myself you can do so by
visiting black magic crafts dot CA there I have my central equipment page where I
link to all of this stuff I use and recommend you can order some on Amazon
and get it safely delivered to your house without having to venture into the
world and another way you can support this channel and me right now always but
especially right now is by joining the black magic crafts fellowship on patreon
that support is always crucial and always meaningful and always much
appreciated right now more than ever we really hope you guys are all doing
well I hope you're staying safe and healthy and I'm gonna do my best to see
you guys again next week Cheers love you all
